recordTypes.name: Zoning Accessory Dwelling Unit (ADU)
recordTypes.description:
Accessory dwelling unit (ADU). A secondary residential living unit on the same lot where the principal use is a legally established single-family dwelling-unit or multi-family dwelling up to three (3) units. An ADU provides separate, complete, independent living facilities with a separate entrance, kitchen, sleeping area, and full bathroom facilities. The ADU may take various forms (i.e., a detached unit, a unit within an accessory structure such as a detached garage, or a unit that is part of an expanded or remodeled primary dwelling).

1.Per RIGL 45-24-37(e) an ADU is permitted as-of-right in all residential zoning districts, in each of the following circumstances.

A.One accessory dwelling unit ("ADU") is permitted on residential property, in either an existing remodeled primary structure, as an addition to an existing primary structure, or within a new primary structure. 

B.One accessory dwelling unit (ADU) is permitted within the existing footprint of an existing detached accessory structure, provided the ADU does not expand the footprint of the structure.

C.One accessory dwelling unit (ADU) in a new development or a new structure is permitted by right on a residential lot with a total area of twenty thousand square feet (20,000 sq. ft.). If such ADU is part of an inclusionary zoning or comprehensive permit application, it may be restricted to affordable housing. See Section 260-50.

2.Tenants of an ADU are not restricted based on familial relationships or age unless required by the terms of a federal, state, or municipal subsidy related to affordability.

3.Private restrictions on ADUs imposed by condominium associations, homeowner associations, or similar residential property governing bodies, which conflict with the provisions of this section or the definition of an ADU as outlined in § 45-24-31, shall be void as against public policy. 

4.The following requirements apply to all ADUs.

(i)An ADU shall have no more than two (2) bedrooms.

(ii)The off-street parking requirement for an ADU shall be no more than one (1) space per bedroom.

(iii)A studio or one-bedroom ADU may contain up to 900 sq. ft., or sixty percent (60%) of the floor area of the principal dwelling unit, whichever is less. For this section, “floor area” shall be defined as heated above-ground living space.

(iv)A two-bedroom ADU may contain up to 1,200 sq. ft., or sixty percent (60%) of the floor area of the principal dwelling unit, whichever is less. For this section, “floor area” shall be defined as heated above-ground living space.

(v)Dimensional requirements applicable to any ADU shall be the same as any accessory or principal structure in the same zoning district. No additional lot area, lot frontage or lot width is required, for both conforming lots and legal nonconforming lots of record, solely to accommodate an ADU.

(vi)ADUs shall not be offered or rented for tourist or transient use through a hosting platform, as such terms are defined in §42-63.1-2.

recordTypes.name: Accessory Structure
recordTypes.description:
An accessory structure is a structure that is clearly incidental to and customarily found in connection with a principal use, is subordinate in size and intensity of use to a principal structure, is located on the same lot as the principal structure being served and contributes to the comfort, convenience, or necessity of the occupants, business, or industry located in the principal structure being served.

Typical Accessory Structures include:  Detached Garage, Shed, Pool, Pool house, Pergola, Gazebo, Tennis Courts.  

Additional information is available online at:   https://ecode360.com/7757422

recordTypes.name: Addition to Structure
recordTypes.description:
Any increase in area of an existing structure (principle, or accessory) including decks, that must comply with the dimensional regulations of the Zoning Ordinance, § 260-19 Minimum dimensional regulations, § 260-20- Standard Dimensional Regulations

Connected structures. Where a structure is within six feet of the principal structure or interconnected to the principal structure (which must include a foundation, walls and a roof), such structure is no longer accessory, but wholly part of the principal structure, and the dimensional and use requirements for a principal structure shall apply.

recordTypes.name: Certificate of Ownership
recordTypes.description:
DBA (Doing Business As) - Registration of Assumed Business Name (the name that will be on the sign for the business)

If you are conducting a business in the Town of Westerly under an assumed business name, or under any designation, name or style, corporate or otherwise, other than the real name or names of the individual or individuals conducting or transacting, Title 6, Chapter 1, of the Rhode Island General Laws requires that the person or persons shall file electronically with the the Town Clerk's Department in the Town or City in which the person or persons conduct, or transact its business.
